Consistent with our scaling story, we can tie pid-limit to memory size since they likely go together.  The bigger decision, IMO, is the addition of a 1GB size.
PG2 1143 ðŸ”µ

*âˆ’2,350*

![](https://media.giphy.com/media/6JxYUOsIdGxag/giphy.gif)

@markusthoemmes @rabbah  
Thanks for explanation.  If I really need some changes on the core, I'll propose PR. :-)

@perryibm : true or false:  if we make the container pool memory size aware, we could/should support any reasonable memory size.   

That is, perhaps we should "do the right thing" and support, say, any multiple of 128 MB up to 2GB.

How do you folks feel about Python 2 vs. Python 3?  In Python 2, virtualenv is the way to go but since Python 3.3 [venv](https://docs.python.org/3/library/venv.html) has been a module in the standard library and since Python 3.5 "**venv is now recommended for creating virtual environments.**".

`$ python3 -m venv . ; . bin/activate`

~I know that OpenWhisk is Python 2 currently but I have been submitting PRs to get us to compatibility with both Py2 and Py3.  I provide some of the reasons for this in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1899 and it has been suggested in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1184#issuecomment-245352118 that we only support one of the two Python versions.~

@cclauss good points - we need to accelerate moving to python 3/adding support so all new changes at in the newer domain. on this note, i think once we have python 3, we can mark python 2 deprecated and eventually remove it.

I think having many multiples of 128MB is fine and would be a good thing when we support memory sizes better in the load balancer/invoker.  I suppose the question is whether we add a 1GB (or 768MB) in the short term.

in the future, do we think we'll have different flavors of invokers?   i.e. segregate "big memory" jobs onto a subset of the invokers?

Seems like it might be a reasonable long-term strategy for managing the bin packing globally and avoid fragmentation ("large object space" anyone?  JikesRVM joke)  
.... but haven't thought it through deeply.

That sort of bin packing works well if there aren't too many sizes because the typical wastage is proportional to the number of sizes you support.   Every multiple of 128MB up to 2GB would be 16 sizes so up to 16 VMs could get wasted in the sense that there could be a VM running just a single 1920MB and other jobs cannot make it there.   The other issue with segregating is that you need to rebalance and dynamically update the invoker flavor and of course this means scheduling to shrink the number of machines as the system detects that a particular size is becoming overprovisioned.  Because of these effects, there is a desire to limit the number of sizes somewhat, a typical sizing (a la free lists) would often be something a little graduated like 128, 256, 384, 512, 768, 1024, 1.25, 1.5, 1.75, 2.
so I wasn't thinking segregated lists for each size -- maybe 2 lists to start ... "up to 256MB" and "up to 2GB"

@rabbah @markusthoemmes @jeremiaswerner @mdeuser 
This is the issue we discussed on direction to remove from openwhisk core the apigateway integration.

The reason it was on this repo was because at the time of initial work for `wsk api-experimental` apigateway was the only way to expose an action as a public api.

Now with webaction in place, and apigateway serving as a add on in front of webactions, apigateway becomes a plugin/extension add on on top of openwhisk core.

@cclauss shouldn't max. line length be according to PEP8; otherwise, it will not considered Pythonic by Python developers?  See https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#maximum-line-length

79 characters is fewer characters than we used to get on punch cards ;-)

Let's start off lenient and then turn the screws later on.  Right now if you click on the `before script` twisty in https://travis-ci.org/openwhisk/openwhisk/builds/208265761 you will see that flake8 currently kicks out **438 errors** and 34 of those are lines longer than 127 characters!  Once we bring those numbers down, we could consider lowering maximum-line-length to the punch card range.

@cclauss I agree. When being exposed to the serious Python world, I was not pleased with most of PEP8 and especially the 79 char limitation/convention.  Again, please read my concession.

I was simply raising the issue, yes of the cold start latency - intuitively, avoiding the write to disk would be prudent, and it's a one line fix. Do we really get significant benefits from writing to disk and loading the modules?

We don't have performance tests that are easily consumable for benchmarking this change - yet. One suggestion is just to do it natively and re-evaluate later.

Deleted the CLI directory as requested.  If this PR is acceptable, please merge; I have "part 2" saved locally and would like to submit those on a separate PR.

A comment on the "api-experimental" and API gateway. The plan is to separate that into an entirely self contained package and CLI plugin. The distinction between the API gateway and web actions reduces to:

1. custom/control over mapping of paths (dont have to follow the openwhisk fully qualified naming)
2. OAuth plugins
3. custom throttling
4. a general API mapping tool, of which some mapping is delegated to openwhisk
5. it's a standalone service (include CLI tooling - or plugin for wsk cli)

Layering`python:2.7.13-alpine`on top of`python:3.6.0-alpine`takes 5 minutes (and adds lots of chatter) to the Travis process and makes openwhisk:dockerskeleton more than twice as big as`python:2.7.13-alpine`.  This might work on a temporary basis but is not optimal for the long term.

```sh
$ docker images
python-2-and-3     146.0 MB
3.6.0-alpine        88.6 MB
2.7.13-alpine       71.5 MB
```

Perhaps we should pull the building of openwhisk:dockerskeleton out of the Travis process or at least put that into the[`before_install`or`before_script`sections](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/.travis.yml#L31-L35) to keep the chatter hidden.  Is there any way to use [Travis build matrix](https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/customizing-the-build/#Build-Matrix) to speed up the builds?
In the openwhisk-client-sdk code as an example app.
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-client-swift?

Ah ok... looking at the doc update, this change is not what I thought it was :) I was expecting/assuming that the user could create their own `Package.swift` with 3rd party deps listed and end up with a zip that contains that whole project pre-compiled and ready to run as an OW action. This change gets us pretty close to that, but I think the end goal would be to add a little more automation to the swift3action container such that the user could run something like:

```bash
$ docker run "$(pwd):/owexec" openwhisk/swift3action createZip
```

Where `$(pwd)` is expected to contain `Package.swift` and all user-written Swift code. Upon completion, the user would find the precompiled action.zip sitting in their cwd.

So... two questions: 
- Is this a reasonable end goal?
- If so, should this PR be merged as-is, or should we wait until the above is supported?

@paulcastro @rabbah @csantanapr @akrabat, thoughts?

>    Is this a reasonable end goal?

yes, i consider that the same as "I expect we all automate the binary building in a systematic way for native actions in the near future." from my earlier comment.

>    If so, should this PR be merged as-is, or should we wait until the above is supported?

+1 for as is - because it is already useful. This is tactical improvement until a more general solution is implemented.
